item.title: List of reported UFO sightings
item.description:
List of Reported UFO Sightings 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides a compilation of notable reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), including claims of close encounters and alien abduction. It clarifies that UFOs encompass any aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified, noting that most are eventually explained as known objects or atmospheric phenomena. The article also mentions the use of the term “Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena” (UAP) to avoid associations with UFO conspiracy theories.

Antiquity 🔗

This section details alleged UFO sightings from ancient times, drawing from historical texts.

  • c. 1450 BC: The Tulli Papyrus describes an event during Thutmose III’s reign in Ancient Egypt, where a “star came down” and set fire to his adversaries.
  • 218 BC: Reports from the Roman Republic in Italia mention “phantom navy” seen shining in the sky.
  • 76 BC: An account from Asia (Roman Republic) describes a “spark” falling from a star, growing to the size of the Moon, and then transforming into a torch.
  • 73 BC: Plutarch recounts a “flame-like body” resembling a wine-jar (pithos) falling between Roman and Pontic armies in Phrygia.
  • AD 65: Flavius Josephus reports chariots “hurtling through the clouds” in Judaea before the First Jewish–Roman War.
  • AD 196: Cassius Dio describes a “fine rain resembling silver” falling from a clear sky in Rome.

8th Century 🔗

This section contains a single entry:

  • c. AD 740: The “Air ship of Clonmacnoise” is recorded in Irish annals, describing “ships with their crews were seen in the air” over Teltown and Clonmacnoise in Ireland.

16th–17th Centuries 🔗

This section lists reports from the Renaissance and early modern periods.

  • 1561: A celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg, Bavaria, is described as an aerial battle with spheres, cylinders, and other odd-shaped objects.
  • 1566: A broadsheet depicts spherical objects appearing out of the sun over Basel, Switzerland.
  • 1609: Multiple witnesses in Joseon (Korea) describe a Halo or washbowl that was divided in two in the sky.

19th Century 🔗

This section covers sightings from the 1800s.

  • 1883: Astronomer José Bonilla photographed hundreds of dark objects crossing the sun at the Zacatecas Observatory in Mexico.
  • 1896-1897: Reports of “mystery airships” with bright lights and cigar-shaped bodies appear in newspapers across California and the Midwest United States.
  • 1897: S.E. Hayden reports the crash of an airship piloted by an alien in Aurora, Texas.

20th Century 🔗

This section is divided into two sub-sections: 1900-1949 and 1950-1974.

1900–1949 🔗

This section covers the early to mid-20th century.

  • 1904: Crew members aboard the USS Supply report seeing three “bright red” objects in geometrical formation flight pattern in the North Pacific.
  • 1907: Fighters of Çerçiz Topulli in Albania report seeing a shiny object suspended in the air.
  • 1909: Moving lights are reported in the sky around Otago, New Zealand, followed by more sightings across the country.
  • 1917: Thousands gather in Fátima, Portugal, and claim to see bizarre solar activity, later interpreted as a mass UFO sighting.
  • 1926: Nicholas Roerich reports an oval object in the sky above his caravan in Tibet.
  • 1933: Frank Smythe witnesses two spots hovering and pulsating in the sky near Mount Everest.
  • 1940s: Allied fighter pilots report colorful balls of light following their aircraft during World War II (Foo fighters).
  • 1941: A local legend emerges in Cape Girardeau, Missouri, about a crashed flying saucer and its dying crew.
  • 1942: Anti-aircraft artillery fires thousands of rounds at an unidentified aerial object over Los Angeles, California (Battle of Los Angeles).
  • 1942: Control tower operator near Flying School, Columbus, Missouri observes two reddish colored round objects descend-hover-accelerate away.
  • 1944: 468th Bomb Group reports an intense red or orange object that throbbed or vibrated constantly.
  • 1945: Conflicting accounts emerge regarding an avocado-shaped craft piloted by insectoid aliens crashing at the Trinity nuclear test site in New Mexico.
  • 1946: Thousands of UFO sightings are reported over Europe (Ghost Rockets), prompting investigations by the Swedish and Greek governments.
  • 1946: Swedish entrepreneur Gösta Carlsson commemorates a 1946 UFO encounter with a concrete monument in Ängelholm, Sweden.
  • 1947: Private pilot Kenneth Arnold reports seeing a group of reflective craft moving at high speeds near Mount Rainier, Washington, coining the term “flying saucers.”
  • 1947: Over 800 similar sightings are reported throughout 1947 after the Kenneth Arnold sighting.
  • 1947: A United Airlines crew witnesses nine unidentified objects en route from Boise, Idaho, to Pendleton, Oregon.
  • 1947: William Albert Rhodes takes photographs of a silent grey object in Phoenix, Arizona.
  • 1947: Walter Haut issues a press release announcing the “capture” of a “flying saucer” near Roswell, New Mexico, later retracted as a weather balloon.
  • 1947: Fred Crisman mails an account of flying doughnut-shaped objects and threats from Men in Black to Raymond A. Palmer (Maury Island hoax).
  • 1948: Reports of green flares streaking across the sky are investigated by the US Air Force (The Green Fireballs).
  • 1948: Captain Thomas F. Mantell dies in the crash of his P-51 Mustang fighter plane near Franklin, Kentucky, after pursuing an unidentified flying object.
  • 1948: Conmen Silas Newton and Leo Gebauer sell “magnetic oil-detecting machines” based on a story about replicated technology from a crashed spaceship (Aztec, New Mexico UFO hoax).
  • 1948: Clarence Chiles and John Whitted report that their airplane nearly collided with a UFO near Montgomery, Alabama.
  • 1948: A US Air Force pilot sights and pursues a UFO for 27 minutes over Fargo, North Dakota (Gorman dogfight).

1950–1974 🔗

This section covers the mid to late 20th century.

  • 1950: A farmer takes pictures of a purported “flying saucer” near McMinnville, Oregon.
  • 1950: The manager of Great Falls’ pro baseball team took color film of two UFOs flying over Great Falls, Montana.
  • 1951: Two pilots and a military officer passenger aboard a commercial DC-3 reported being buzzed by an unidentified straight-winged plane over Sioux City, Iowa.
  • 1951: Several lights in V-shaped formations were repeatedly spotted flying over the city of Lubbock, Texas.
  • 1952: Four American military personnel aboard two different B-29 bombers reported seeing an orange globe-shaped light over two different cities in northern Korea.
  • 1952: A series of sightings accompanied radar contacts in the Washington, D.C. area.
  • 1952: William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, pilots of a DC-4 airliner of Pan American Airways, radioed the Norfolk civil aviation authority to report eight large, round, glowing red objects.
  • 1952: Three local boys followed a bright object into the forest to what they believed was a UFO landing in Flatwoods, West Virginia.
  • 1954: French metalworker Marius Dewilde claimed to have become a contactee in Quarouble, France.
  • 1954: A football game between Fiorentina and Pistoiese was under way at the Stadio Artemio Franchi in Florence when a group of UFOs traveling at high speed abruptly stopped over the stadium.
  • 1955: Eleven people witnessed creatures in the night at a rural farmhouse near Hopkinsville, Kentucky.
  • 1956: United States Air Force (USAF) and Royal Air Force (RAF) radar operators detected up to 15 objects over Suffolk, England.
  • 1956: Elizabeth Klarer claimed detailed adventures with an alien race including having had an alien lover, Akon, who would have fathered her son Ayling in Drakens

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UFO_sightings

item.title: Perspectives on the alien abduction phenomenon
item.description:
Perspectives on the Alien Abduction Phenomenon 🔗

This explores various explanations for claims of alien abduction and examination by otherworldly beings. Perspectives range from complete disbelief to the acceptance of these claims as objective reality. Some researchers, like Harvard psychiatrist John E. Mack, acknowledge an “authentic mystery” surrounding the phenomenon, urging consideration of all associated aspects, including missing time, UFO sightings, and occurrences in children. The mainstream scientific view leans towards a psychosocial explanation rooted in human psychology, neurology, and culture, while others, including conspiracy theorists and ufologists, believe in literal extraterrestrial abductions. Authors like Jacques Vallée and John E. Mack suggest the need to re-evaluate our understanding of reality to comprehend the phenomenon fully.

Extraterrestrial Hypothesis 🔗

This section presents the idea that alien abduction is a real phenomenon where extraterrestrial beings abduct humans for study or experimentation. The elusiveness of these beings is attributed to their advanced technology. The hypothesis lacks widespread support among mainstream scientists due to the absence of physical evidence and the contradictory nature of abduction accounts.

Literary Perspectives 🔗

This section explores the appeal of alien abduction accounts from a literary standpoint. Terry Matheson suggests that these tales are captivating due to their depiction of human powerlessness. The section contrasts the temporary fear experienced from ghost stories with the inescapable nature of alien abductions, which the abduction myth suggests cannot be avoided.

Skeptical Perspectives 🔗

This section outlines skeptical explanations for alien abduction reports, focusing on psychological processes rather than extraterrestrial beings. Skeptics critically examine claims for evidence of hoaxes or influence from popular culture. Brian Dunning notes psychological explanations such as hallucination, temporary schizophrenia, epileptic seizures, and parasomnia (including hypnagogic states, night terrors, and sleep paralysis). Sleep paralysis, often accompanied by hallucinations, is presented as a potential explanation, although individuals experiencing it do not typically interpret it as alien encounters.

Hoax 🔗

This section addresses the possibility of alien abduction claims being hoaxes, motivated by financial gain or attention. While some skeptics believe abductees are lying, it is acknowledged that most abductees genuinely believe in their experiences, making simple fabrication an insufficient explanation for the majority of claims.

Psychopathology 🔗

This section discusses the view, once common but now largely unsupported by scientists, that those claiming alien abduction are mentally ill. Studies have found that alleged abductees are generally no more likely to suffer from psychopathologies than the general population. However, abductees often score higher in tests measuring hypnotic suggestibility, absorption, magical ideation, and dissociative experiences.

False Memory Hypothesis 🔗

This section presents the false memory hypothesis, a widely accepted theory in the scientific community, which explains how psychologically healthy individuals may develop and maintain a belief in alien abduction through psychological processes.

Sleep Paralysis 🔗

This section details how sleep paralysis, often accompanied by feelings of chest pressure and hypnopompic hallucinations (such as flying, lights, presences, and figures), can contribute to abduction experiences. Cultural beliefs strongly influence the content of these hallucinations. Carl Sagan’s comparison of alien abduction experiences to historical tales of demon abduction is highlighted.

Lucid Dreams 🔗

This section explores the connection between lucid dreams and alien abduction experiences. Research from the Phase Research Center suggests that experiences of close encounters with UFOs and extraterrestrials can be products of the human mind during lucid dreaming. A 2021 study found that a significant percentage of volunteers could emulate alien encounters via lucid dreams, with some experiencing sleep paralysis and fear similar to “real” abduction stories.

Hypnosis 🔗

This section discusses the use of hypnosis in recovering memories of “missing time” in abduction cases, starting with the Betty and Barney Hill abduction. It notes that individuals interested in UFOs may seek therapists with similar beliefs, potentially leading to the creation of false memories under hypnosis due to increased suggestibility. Thomas Bullard notes that hypnotized subjects are more likely to confabulate or be open to memory implantation. Budd Hopkins’ counterargument, citing the Hill case, is also presented. Skeptics Robert Sheaffer and Phillip J. Klass suggest that individual abduction researchers influence the characteristics of narratives retrieved during hypnotic recall.

Cultural Impact 🔗

This section examines the influence of cultural factors on abduction claims. Skeptics argue that variations in abduction details across cultures support a psycho-social hypothesis. The section notes that abduction accounts may be influenced by science fiction, citing the resemblance between the Betty and Barney Hill case and media they had recently consumed. It also mentions how abduction claims have changed over time to align with scientific discoveries about the solar system. Robert Sheaffer highlights differences in the types of aliens reported in different countries and similarities between aliens in early science fiction films and abduction reports.

Maintenance of Abduction Memories 🔗

This section discusses how abductees maintain their beliefs, even when faced with disbelief. Many seek support groups where they find validation from others with similar experiences, reinforcing the accuracy of their abduction memories.

Drug-Induced Hallucinations 🔗

This section explores the possibility that some alleged abductions are drug-induced hallucinations. It mentions Terence McKenna’s experiences with “Machine Elves” while using DMT and Rick Strassman’s research at the University of New Mexico, which found that a significant percentage of volunteers injected with high doses of DMT had experiences similar to purported alien abductions.

Parallels with Other Phenomena 🔗

This section draws parallels between the abduction phenomenon and other unusual events, such as witchcraft claims. Robert Sheaffer notes similarities in imagery, uncovered memories, and sex, suggesting a common underlying psychopathology.

This section also notes Gwen Dean’s presentation of 44 parallels between alien abduction and satanic ritual abuse (SRA) at a 1992 MIT conference. Both phenomena emerged in the late 1970s and early 1980s, often use hypnosis, and feature similar elements such as familial involvement, generational occurrences, examination tables/altars, focus on genitals/sexuality/breeding, altered states of consciousness, and “missing time.”

Abductors as Demonic Manifestations 🔗

This section presents the view that abduction experiences share similarities with pre-20th century accounts of demonic manifestations. Writers have noted numerous similarities. Fr. Seraphim Rose, an Orthodox monk, dedicates a chapter in his book Orthodoxy and the Religion of the Future to UFOs and abductions, concluding that they are manifestations of the demonic.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspectives_on_the_abduction_phenomenon

item.title: Resident Alien (American television series)
item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) 🔗

This is a comprehensive description of the Wikipedia article for the American television series Resident Alien.

Overview 🔗

This section provides a brief introduction to the television series Resident Alien. It establishes the show’s genre as a science fiction mystery comedy-drama and identifies Chris Sheridan as the creator. It also mentions that the show is based on the comic book series of the same name by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse. The premiere date of the first season on Syfy is noted, along with the star, Alan Tudyk. The renewals for subsequent seasons, including the move to USA Network for the fourth season, are also mentioned.

Premise 🔗

This section outlines the central plot of the series. An alien arrives on Earth with the mission to wipe out humanity. After crashing in Colorado, the alien assumes the identity of a doctor named Harry Vanderspeigle. As he lives among humans, he begins to question his mission. A young boy, Max Hawthorne, can see through his disguise. The alien grapples with his mission and ultimately defends humanity from other extraterrestrial threats.

Cast and characters 🔗

This section details the main and recurring cast members and their respective characters.

Main 🔗

  • Alan Tudyk plays the alien, who takes on the identity of Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle. He is sent to Earth to destroy humanity but develops compassion. Tudyk also portrays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle.
  • Sara Tomko plays Asta Twelvetrees, the assistant to the town doctor and a member of the Ute tribe. She is the first person after Max to discover Harry’s true identity.
  • Corey Reynolds plays Sheriff Mike Thompson, the town’s sheriff, who is dealing with past trauma.
  • Alice Wetterlund plays D’arcy Bloom, the owner of the town pub and Asta’s best friend. She discovers Harry’s true identity after learning that the real Harry killed Sam Hodges.
  • Levi Fiehler plays Ben Hawthorne, the town’s mayor, who has a history of alien abductions.
  • Judah Prehn plays Max Hawthorne, Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen plays Deputy Liv Baker, the town’s deputy, who is fascinated by extraterrestrials.

Recurring 🔗

This section lists actors and the recurring characters they portray, including:

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach
  • Justin Rain as Elliot
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins
  • Enver Gjokaj as Joseph Rainier
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget”
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner

Guest 🔗

This section lists actors and the guest characters they portray, including:

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop
  • Grace Sunar as Mari
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan

Episodes 🔗

This section provides an overview of the series’ episodes, broken down by season.

Series overview 🔗

This subsection presents a table summarizing the number of episodes per season, the original release dates, and the network on which each season aired.

Season 1 (2021) 🔗

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 10 episodes of the first season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Season 2 (2022) 🔗

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 16 episodes of the second season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot. The season is split into two parts, each with eight episodes.

Season 3 (2024) 🔗

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 8 episodes of the third season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Production 🔗

This section details the development, casting, and filming aspects of the series.

Development 🔗

This subsection explains the origins of the series, stating that Chris Sheridan was inspired by the novels and comic book series of the same name. It also mentions Sheridan’s personal experience with a UFO sighting as inspiration. The initial pilot order by Syfy, along with the involvement of Universal Cable Productions, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Amblin Television, is mentioned. The series order, production location in Vancouver, and David Dobkin’s role as director and executive producer are also noted.

Casting 🔗

This subsection lists the initial casting announcements, including Alan Tudyk as the lead, along with Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler. It also mentions the casting of Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, Alex Barima, and Elizabeth Bowen in recurring roles.

Filming 🔗

This subsection provides information on the filming locations and timelines for each season. Principal photography for the first season took place in Delta, British Columbia, Canada. Filming details for the second and third seasons are also included.

Release 🔗

This section details the release dates of the series. Syfy initially announced a summer 2020 premiere, which was later moved to January 2021. International premiere dates in Canada and the United Kingdom are also mentioned.

Reception 🔗

This section summarizes the critical reception and ratings of the series.

Critical response 🔗

This subsection presents the review scores from Rotten Tomatoes and Metacritic for the first and second seasons, highlighting the positive critical reception.

Ratings 🔗

This subsection provides a table with viewership and ratings per episode for the first season.

Accolades 🔗

This section lists the awards and nominations received by the series, including those from the Saturn Awards, Critics Choice Super Awards, Dragon Awards, and Hollywood Critics Association Television Awards.

Notes 🔗

This section provides clarifying information and context for certain details within the article, such as character name spellings, guest star credits, and rating metrics.

References 🔗

This section contains a list of citations used throughout the article, providing sources for the information presented.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to the official website and the IMDb page for the series.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction 🔗

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. These individuals are often referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” While most scientists and mental health professionals attribute these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology, some researchers give credence to the claims. Typical claims involve forced medical examinations, often focusing on reproductive systems, warnings about environmental abuses and nuclear weapons, or interspecies breeding. The content of these narratives often varies with the abductee’s cultural background.

Overview 🔗

Mainstream scientists generally reject the literal interpretation of alien abduction claims. However, some, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that many abductees are sane individuals, with psychopathology only present in some cases. Detailed abduction reports have led to the development of a subculture with support groups and a complex mythos explaining the roles, origins, and motivations of various alien types, such as Greys, Reptilians, and Nordics. Some abductees engage in independent research and attribute the lack of wider awareness to extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History 🔗

Paleo-abductions 🔗

Before the widespread attention to alien abduction in the 1960s, some older stories have been reinterpreted as possible early cases, termed “paleo-abductions” by UFO researcher Jerome Clark. One example is Colonel H. G. Shaw’s 1896 claim of being harassed by tall, slender humanoids. An article from 1953 asked if flying saucers were kidnapping humans for zoological specimens or vivisection. The 1955 publication of Harold T. Wilkins’s Flying Saucers Uncensored reported speculation that Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who claimed alien contact, disappeared due to abduction.

Two landmark cases 🔗

The Antônio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil during the mid-1950s was an early claim but received limited attention initially. The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961 gained widespread publicity, including a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, possibly the first to describe beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identify an extraterrestrial origin.

Later developments 🔗

R. Leo Sprinkle, a psychologist at the University of Wyoming, became interested in the phenomenon in the 1960s and linked abductions to cattle mutilation. Budd Hopkins became a key figure in the abductee subculture in the 1970s, using hypnosis to uncover details of remembered events. The 1980s saw increased mainstream attention, with works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack presenting alien abduction as a plausible experience. Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published.

Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was more common than previously thought, estimating tens of thousands of North Americans had been abducted. They also proposed an alien effort to create human-alien hybrids. While anecdotal reports of phantom pregnancies related to UFO encounters existed earlier, Hopkins and Jacobs popularized the idea of widespread interbreeding efforts.

According to Boston Globe writer Linda Rodriguez McRobbie, alien abduction stories have declined in mainstream media. Michael Shermer suggests that the ubiquity of camera phones has increased the burden of evidence, contributing to the decline.

John E. Mack 🔗

Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, suggested that Mack’s work in hypnotic regression helped spread the Grey aliens meme. Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject. His professional reputation suffered due to his belief and promotion of abduction claims, leading to a Harvard review in 1994.

Abductees 🔗

The precise number of alleged abductees is uncertain. Early studies found 1,700 claimants, while contested surveys suggested 5–6 percent of the general population claim to have been abducted.

Demographics 🔗

While abduction reports are usually made by adults, children sometimes report similar experiences. These reports often share specific details with adult reports, including circumstances, narrative, entities, and aftermaths. Young abductees often have family members who have reported abduction experiences, and family involvement in the military or residence near a military base is also common.

Mental health 🔗

Some studies suggest that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that abductees are not different from the general population in terms of psychopathology prevalence. Elizabeth Slater’s blind study found abductees prone to “mildly paranoid thinking,” nightmares, and weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally’s study concluded that none of the abductees suffered from psychiatric illness.

Political conspiracy theories 🔗

Political scientist Michael Barkun highlights links between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, environmental pollution, hidden groups, and government takeover. He observed the rise of “improvisional millenarism.” UFO and abduction stories can be part of stigmatized knowledge narratives. UFO and alien-related conspiracy theories emerged in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards.

According to Barkun, TV shows like The X-Files included aliens as part of coverup conspiracies, with militias and black helicopters, and demonized FEMA. Political scientist Jodi Dean noted that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities.

Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities and may resort to questionable regression therapy. Some espouse conspiracy theories of technological mind control, including implants, to force them to serve a New World Order or for the purposes of the antichrist.

Abduction narrative 🔗

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. CUFOS defines an abductee as someone taken against their will by non-human beings to an extraterrestrial place or spaceship, subjected to examination or communication, with memories that may be conscious or recovered through hypnosis.

Although cases vary, some UFO researchers argue that there is a fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.”

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures, and on occasion simulated behavioral situations, training & testing, or sexual liaisons.
  3. Conference: The abductors communicate with the abductee or direct them to interact with specific individuals for some purpose.
  4. Tour: The abductees are given a tour of their captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Abductees often rapidly forget the majority of their experience.
  6. Return: The abductees are returned to earth, occasionally in a different location or with new injuries.
  7. Theophany: Abductees may have a profound sense of love, a “high” similar to those induced by certain drugs, or a “mystical experience”.
  8. Aftermath: The abductee must cope with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs says that the entire abduction event is precisely orchestrated, with predetermined procedures.

Capture 🔗

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience, such as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place or expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will occur. They also report feeling severe anxiety. Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. External sounds cease to have any significance, and they report feeling introspective and unusually calm. As consciousness shifts, lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist. As the alleged abduction proceeds, claimants say they will walk or be levitated into an alien craft, often through solid objects.

Examination 🔗

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. Such procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. The entity in charge of the operation is often taller than the others and may appear to be of a different species.

Miller notes different areas of emphasis between human medicine and what is reported as being practiced by the abductors. The abductors’ areas of interest appear to be the cranium, nervous system, skin, reproductive system, and joints. Systems given less attention include the cardiovascular system, the respiratory system below the pharynx, and the lymphatic system. The abductors also appear to ignore the upper region of the abdomen in favor of the lower one. The abductors do not appear to wear gloves during the “examination.” Other constants of terrestrial medicine like pills and tablets are missing from abduction narratives, although sometimes abductees are asked to drink liquids.

Subsequent procedures 🔗

After the medical exam, the alleged abductees often report other procedures being performed with the entities. Common among these post-examination procedures are imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

“Imaging” procedures consist of an abductee being made to view screens displaying images and scenes that appear to be specially chosen with the intent to provoke certain emotional responses in the abductee. “Envisioning” is a similar procedure, with the primary difference being that the images being viewed, rather than being on a screen, actually seem to be

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction

item.title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024
item.description:
National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024 🔗

The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024 (NDAA 2024) is a United States federal law that outlines the budget, expenditures, and policies of the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) for fiscal year 2024.

Background 🔗

The National Defense Authorization Act is an annual bill proposed in the United States Congress that redefines the United States military budget for the following fiscal year. Each chamber of Congress introduced a version of the NDAA: H.R. 2670 in the House and S. 2226 in the Senate.

History 🔗

The House passed their version on July 14, 2023 by a vote of 219–210. Led by Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds, the Senate passed theirs on July 27, 2023 by a vote of 86–11. The Senate then replaced H.R. 2670 with the text of S. 2226 and passed it by unanimous consent, and indefinitely postponed S. 2226. The House disagreed to the Senate amendment and asked to hold conference on September 19, with the Senate insisting on its amendment and agreeing to conference on November 15. The subsequent conference report was filed on December 6 (H. Rept. 118-301). The bill was approved by the Senate and House and sent to President Joe Biden on December 14. Biden signed it into law on December 22. In his signing statement, Biden expressed reservations about provisions that restrict the executive branch’s discretion in Guantanamo detainee transfers and raised constitutional concerns regarding congressional oversight and foreign policy authority.

Provisions 🔗

This section requires updating to reflect recent events or newly available information.

Unidentified flying objects (UFOs) 🔗

Sections 1841 et seq. outline the creation and management of a comprehensive collection of government records on UFOs or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) at the National Archives (NARA), detailing the processes for assembling, preserving, and providing public access to these records, along with specific protocols for their review, disclosure, and secure handling. NARA subsequently provided guidance to federal agencies to identify, organize, and disclose UAP records for the new collection.

Sections 1687 and 7343 disallow use of funds or independent research and development (IRAD) indirect expenses for UFOs or UAP unless such material and information is made available the appropriate congressional committees and congressional leadership.

Language on the topic of UFO/UAP was also included in the previous 2023 NDAA, the 2022 NDAA, the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, as well as an accompanying Senate Select Committee on Intelligence report for the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021.

Foreign Extortion Prevention Act 🔗

The Foreign Extortion Prevention Act (FEPA) enables US authorities to prosecute foreign officials who demand or accept bribes from a US citizen, US company, or within a US jurisdiction. FEPA addresses a longstanding gap in US anti-bribery legislation by tackling the “demand” side of bribery. At the same time, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) focuses on the “supply” side of bribery.

Counter-extremist working group defunded 🔗

Republicans opposed the anti-extremism working group created by Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin. That working group had been created by Austin after it became apparent that some service members and veterans had participated in the attack on the US Capitol January 6, 2021. That working group released recommendations at the end of 2021. Implementation, however, appeared to stall as Republicans increasingly opposed diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in the military, which Republicans derided as “wokeness”.

Meanwhile, a recent inspector general report found dozens of troops, who appeared to be advocating violent overthrow of the US government.

The seriousness of this issue seems apparent from the fact that military and veterans have participated in other violent extremist events. For example, the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, had served with distinction in Operation Desert Storm but had earned a reputation as a sergeant for assigning undesirable work to black servicemen and using derogatory language.

NATO withdrawal 🔗

Section 1250A prevents the President from withdrawing the United States from NATO without the approval of a two-thirds Senate supermajority or an act of Congress.

Original proposals 🔗

The original House bill contained provisions to:

  • Space Force Personnel Management Act: Disestablish the regular Space Force in order to integrate both active duty and reserve personnel into one Space Force entity. This is to allow for better flexibility for the Space Force by replacing “active duty” with “sustained duty” or “full-time” status, and replacing “reserve” with “part-time” status. This change would only pertain to the Space Force and not to the other armed services.
  • Elevate the position of vice chief of the National Guard Bureau to hold a statutory rank of general.
  • Permanently establish the titles of commissioned officer ranks of the Space Force to be the same as the Army, Marine Corps, and Air Force.
  • Authorize a $886 billion spending budget for national defense programs including:
    • A 5.2% pay increase for service members of the armed forces.
    • Procurement of up to 13 Virginia-class submarines.
  • Authorize the sale and transfer of defense articles and services relating to the implementation of the AUKUS partnership, including:
    • Up to three Virginia-class submarines, one year after this act is passed, however the Navy doesn’t intend implement this until 2032.

The Senate amendment contained:

  • UAP Disclosure Act: The Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Disclosure Act of 2023 would direct the National Archives and Records Administration to collect and disclose records on unidentified flying objects (UFOs) or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) no later than 25 years after enactment with a presumption of immediate disclosure. The U.S. president can certify that continued postponement can be made necessary by an identifiable harm to military defense, intelligence operations, law enforcement or conduct of foreign relations. The federal government would have eminent domain over recovered technologies of unknown origin (TUO) and biological evidence of non-human intelligence (NHI) that may be controlled by private persons or entities, such as aerospace companies. Legislation was necessary in part because UAP records had not been subject to mandatory declassification review due to exemptions under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 as well as an over-broad interpretation of “transclassified foreign nuclear information”.
  • The Intelligence Authorization Act (IAA) requires people currently or formerly under contract with the federal government to make all UFO/UAP material and information and a comprehensive list of all extraterrestrial or exotic UAP material available to the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO).
  • A provision that prevents the President of the United States from withdrawing the U.S. from NATO without approval of a two-thirds Senate supermajority or an act of Congress.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unidentified_Anomalous_Phenomena_Disclosure_Act

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 🔗

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s generally believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The USAF and CIA acquired the site in 1955, primarily for flight testing the Lockheed U-2 aircraft. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it a frequent subject of conspiracy theories and a central component of unidentified flying object (UFO) folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. It’s located in southern Nevada, approximately 83 miles (134 km) north-northwest of Las Vegas.

Geography 🔗

This section details the physical location and surrounding areas of Area 51. The original base was a 6 by 10 mile rectangle, part of the larger “Groom box,” a 23 by 25 mile area of restricted airspace. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and eventually connects to State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel, Nevada. Area 51 shares a border with the Yucca Flat region of the Nevada Test Site, where many US nuclear tests were conducted. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository is southwest of Groom Lake. Groom Lake itself is a salt flat used for runways.

History 🔗

The origin of the name “Area 51” is uncertain. The CIA refers to the facility as Homey Airport (XTA/KXTA) and Groom Lake. Other nicknames include “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch.” The special use airspace is Restricted Area 4808 North (R-4808N). Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, and mining operations occurred until the early 1950s. The airfield began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program 🔗

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE, the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. sought a secure testing site. Lockheed’s Kelly Johnson found Groom Lake ideal due to the dry lake bed and surrounding mountain ranges. The CIA acquired the land from the AEC, designating it “Area 51.” Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch.” A survey team arrived in May 1955, laying out a runway and base support facility. The Ranch initially consisted of shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. By July 1955, the base had a paved runway, three hangars, a control tower, and accommodations for personnel. The first U-2 delivery arrived on July 24, 1955. Regular flights were established between Area 51 and Lockheed’s Burbank offices.

OXCART program 🔗

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. Groom Lake’s facilities were initially inadequate. Construction of “Project 51” began in September 1960, including a new 8,500 ft runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) upgraded base facilities. A 10,000 ft runway (14/32) was built, and an Archimedean spiral was marked on the dry lake as an overrun. Three Navy hangars were erected, and the original U-2 hangars were converted to maintenance shops. Facilities included workshops, storage, administration buildings, a commissary, a control tower, a fire station, and housing. A permanent aircraft fuel tank farm was constructed for the JP-7 fuel required by the A-12. Security was enhanced, and the FAA expanded the restricted airspace. The CIA facility received USAF F-101 Voodoos, T-33 Shooting Star trainers, a C-130 Hercules, a U-3A, a helicopter, a Cessna 180, and an F-104 Starfighter. The first A-12 test aircraft arrived in February 1962 and made its first flight on April 26, 1962. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron”.

D-21 Tagboard 🔗

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2, discussions arose about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The Air Force agreed to fund the study of a high-speed, high-altitude drone aircraft in October 1962, designated “Q-12,” later renamed the “D-21.” “Tagboard” was the project’s code name. The D-21 was to be carried by a two-seat derivative of the A-12, designated the “M-21.” Difficulties were addressed throughout 1964 and 1965. The first D-21 launch was made on March 5, 1966, with a successful flight. An accident on July 30, 1966, caused the D-21 to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft, resulting in one crew member drowning. Kelly Johnson cancelled the program. The Air Force proposed launching them from a B-52H bomber. The test missions were flown out of Groom Lake, with the actual launches over the Pacific. Several more tests were made, none of which met with success. The D-21B program was cancelled on July 15, 1971. The remaining drones were transferred to the Davis-Monthan AFB Military Storage and Disposition Center.

Foreign technology evaluation 🔗

During the Cold War, the United States tested and evaluated captured Soviet fighter aircraft. Beginning in the late 1960s, Area 51 hosted Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate their performance and capabilities, pitting them against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT. Comparisons between the F-4 and the MiG-21 indicated that the skill of the pilot was what made the difference. On August 12, 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel with a pair of MiG-17Fs. These MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. The aircraft were given USAF designations and fake serial numbers. The data from the HAVE DOUGHNUT and HAVE DRILL tests were provided to the newly formed Top Gun school at NAS Miramar. In May 1973, Project HAVE IDEA was formed, and the project was transferred to the Tonopah Test Range Airport. Area 51 also hosted another foreign materiel evaluation program called HAVE GLIB. The Air Force began funding improvements to Area 51 in 1977 under project SCORE EVENT. In 1979, the CIA transferred jurisdiction of the Area 51 site to the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards AFB, California. In 2017, a USAF aircraft crashed at the site, killing the pilot, Lt. Colonel Eric “Doc” Schultz.

Have Blue/F-117 program 🔗

The Lockheed Have Blue prototype stealth fighter first flew at Groom in December 1977. In 1978, the Air Force awarded a full-scale development contract for the F-117 to Lockheed Corporation’s Advanced Development Projects. On January 17, 1981, the Lockheed test team at Area 51 accepted delivery of the first full-scale development (FSD) prototype, designated YF-117A. On June 18, 1981, Lockheed Skunk Works test pilot Hal Farley lifted the nose of YF-117A off the runway of Area 51. Tactical Air Command (TAC) decided to set up a group-level organization to guide the F-117A to an initial operating capability, the 4450th Tactical Group, which officially activated on October 15, 1979, at Nellis AFB, Nevada, although the group was physically located at Area 51. The 4450th TG also operated the A-7D Corsair II as a surrogate trainer for the F-117A. On October 15, 1982, Major Alton C. Whitley Jr. became the

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_51

item.title: List of UFO religions
item.description:
UFO Religions 🔗

UFO religions are groups that incorporate beliefs about communication with extraterrestrial beings into their religious doctrines. These groups often interpret major religions as being based on supernatural beings from heaven. Communication methods include telepathy and astral projection. A common belief is that humanity can be saved through education provided by aliens, leading to societal improvement. Alien abduction experiences can also contribute to the formation of these religions.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for understanding UFO religions. It highlights that these religions generally involve belief in communication with extraterrestrial beings, often through physical contact, telepathy, or astral projection. These groups typically believe that aliens will save humanity by teaching them a better way to live, sometimes by taking believers to a more positive location. UFO religions emphasize spiritual growth and the evolution of humanity.

J. Gordon Melton is identified as considering the “I AM” Activity, founded by Guy Ballard, as the first UFO religion. However, Christopher Hugh Partridge views it as a theosophical religion rather than a UFO religion. Partridge emphasizes the belief within UFO religions that supreme beings originate from other planets or planes, not from Earth.

The Roswell incident of 1947 is identified as a key event in the history of UFO spirituality, marking the emergence of UFOs into public consciousness. UFO religion is placed within the context of theosophical esotericism and New Age thought, with many groups believing that extraterrestrial beings are heralds of a new era.

The Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, is described as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults. Heaven’s Gate and the Order of the Solar Temple are mentioned as controversial groups combining UFO beliefs with contactee assertions. Scientology is also discussed as a UFO religion due to its Xenu cosmogony and space opera elements.

List 🔗

This section provides a table listing various UFO religions, their founders, and the year they were founded. The list includes:

  • Aetherius Society: Founded by George King in 1955.
  • Ashtar Galactic Command: Founded by Thelma B. Terrill (“Tuella”) in 1977.
  • CEIRUS: Founded by Jean Miguères in 1987.
  • Chen Tao: Founded by Hon-ming Chen in 1993.
  • Christ Brotherhood: Founded by Wallace C. Halsey in 1956.
  • Cosmic Circle of Fellowship: Founded by William R. Ferguson in 1955.
  • Fiat Lux: Founded by Uriella in 1980.
  • Freie Interessengemeinschaft für Grenz- und Geisteswissenschaften und Ufologiestudien: Founded by Billy Meier in the 1970s.
  • Ground Crew Project: Founded by Sheldon Nidle in the 1980s.
  • Heaven’s Gate: Founded by Marshall Applewhite and Bonnie Nettles in the 1970s.
  • “I AM” Activity: Founded by Guy Ballard in the 1930s.
  • Industrial Church of the New World Comforter: Founded by Allen Michael in 1973.
  • Mark-Age: Founded by Charles Boyd Gentzel and Pauline Sharpe in 1962.
  • Nation of Islam: Founded by Wallace Fard Muhammad in 1930.
  • Néo-Phare: Founded by Arnaud Mussy in 2001.
  • Nuwaubian Nation: Founded by Dwight York in the 1970s.
  • Order of the Solar Temple: Founded by Joseph Di Mambro and Luc Jouret in 1984.
  • Raëlism: Founded by Raël in 1974.
  • Rational Culture: Founded by Manoel Jacintho Coelho in the 1930s.
  • Sanctuary of Thought: Founded by Truman Bethurum in the 1950s.
  • The Seekers: Founded by Charles Laughead (aka “Dr. Armstrong”) or Dorothy Martin (aka “Marian Keech”) in 1953.
  • Siderella: Founded by Jean-Paul Appel-Guéry.
  • Scientology: Founded by L. Ron Hubbard in 1952.
  • Unarius: Founded by Ernest Norman and Ruth Norman in 1954.
  • Universe People: Founded by Ivo A. Benda in 1997.
  • Urantia movement: Authorship of The Urantia Book is unknown and disputed. The book alleges it was written by celestial beings. Founded between 1924 and 1955.
  • Vale do Amanhecer: Founded by Neiva Chaves Zelaya in the 1960s.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and links for further exploration, including:

  • Religion portal
  • Outer space portal
  • Doomsday cult
  • List of new religious movements
  • List of ufologists
  • List of UFO organizations

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UFO_religions

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation 🔗

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle and other animals under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon has been linked to paranormal and supernatural explanations, as well as more mundane causes. Mutilations typically involve the removal of organs such as the eyes, tongue, and genitals. Reports of such incidents span the globe, involving various livestock and wild animals. Explanations range from natural decomposition and predation to cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. The United States has conducted two federal investigations into the matter.

Early History 🔗

Documented reports of unexplained livestock deaths date back to 1606 in England, where sheep were found slaughtered with only tallow and some inward parts removed. Charles Fort collected accounts of similar mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 🔗

The unexplained death and mutilation of a horse named “Snippy” in Alamosa, Colorado, in 1967 brought the phenomenon to wider attention. The Pueblo Chieftain published a story about the incident, detailing the horse’s skinned and defleshed head and neck, as well as precise cuts on the body. The lack of blood and a medicinal odor at the scene fueled speculation about extraterrestrial involvement. Wadsworth Ayer’s investigation for the Condon Committee concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Sheriff Ben Phillips initially attributed the death to a lightning strike. Later, two students confessed to shooting the horse weeks after the incident gained publicity.

Cattle Mutilations 1973–1980 🔗

This period saw a surge in reported cattle mutilations across Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico. Unidentified helicopters were reported in connection with cattle and pig rustling in Western Iowa (April 1973) and Missouri (August 1973).

1973 Kansas Wave 🔗

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about suspicious phone calls from someone posing as a USDA official. Several butchered cows were subsequently found in the county, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” butcher. By December, law enforcement reported a wave of cattle deaths in seven counties across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, a conclusion disputed by Modlin.

1974 Nebraska Wave 🔗

Reports continued in April 1974 with a mutilated and blood-drained cow in Nebraska. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. Mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, with coyotes blamed. By June, Lancaster County, Nebraska, reported mutilations. Custer County reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. In August, an unidentified helicopter was spotted shining a spotlight over a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols due to helicopter sightings. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh suggested devil-worshiping cultists were responsible. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By late August, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when a helicopter was spotted above his field. Authorities cautioned against shooting at aircraft. In September, an autopsy revealed a supposedly-mutilated cow died of bacterial infection. Over 50 law enforcement officials attended a meeting in Center, Nebraska, estimating 27 out of 80 cow deaths were suspected mutilations. South Dakota also reported alleged mutilations. Newsweek became the first national outlet to cover the story, reporting 100 cattle mutilated in Nebraska, Kansas, and Iowa since May. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande confirmed mutilation reports in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. Minnesota reported mutilations in Kandiyohi, Swift, and Meeker counties.

1975 Colorado 🔗

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico 🔗

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting 🔗

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations, attended by about 80 people. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. In May, Valdez reported finding two drugs in a mutilated bull’s remains: Chlorpromazine (Thorazine) to tranquilize the animal and another to clog the blood. In June 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents 🔗

Many mutilation cases have been reported worldwide since 1967, primarily in the Americas and Australia. South America has seen an estimated 3,500 incidents since 2002. Investigators believe many cases go unreported. In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of São Paulo, Brazil, in 1988. Theories ranged from homicide to alien abduction.

Characteristics 🔗

Cattle deaths due to natural causes are common. However, ranchers began reporting unusual deaths characterized by missing sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts were described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals were reported drained of blood with no blood at the scene. Howard Burgess noted that nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints have been found near mutilation sites. The “Snippy” case featured an absence of tracks and small holes “punched” in the ground. In Rio Arriba County, New Mexico, a “trail of suction cup-like impressions” was found leading from a mutilated cow.

Laboratory Reports 🔗

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. However, these anomalies are not consistent across all cases. In a case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI involving a bull belonging to Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, the animal displayed “classic” mutilation signs. The liver and heart were white and mushy, with the texture of peanut butter. Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory detected Clostridium bacteria in the heart but could not draw conclusions. Liver samples were devoid of copper and contained high levels of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were light pink and did not clot. The animal’s hide was brittle, and the flesh was discolored.

Helicopter Sightings 🔗

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters reportedly opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. This followed a series of alleged mutilations in the area. In August 1974, residents reported seeing unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. Know County Sheriff Herbert Thompson claimed helicopter sightings were nightly occurrences. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. Authorities ran ads urging ranchers not to shoot at survey helicopters. The National Guard warned its helicopter pilots to fly at higher altitudes. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. After this encounter, cattle mutilations in the region ceased for about five years. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter hovering around a site following a wave of alleged mutilations.

Official Investigations 🔗

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms 🔗

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger, tasked with investigating possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents and circumstantial evidence but found insufficient evidence of cult involvement. His investigation was dropped when it was determined cattle deaths were not a prelude to a coordinated campaign against elected officials.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation 🔗

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University, but no conclusive results emerged. A $40,000 reward was offered. The US Bureau of Land Management

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle_mutilation

item.title: Uncontacted peoples
item.description:
Uncontacted Peoples 🔗

Uncontacted peoples are Indigenous groups who live without sustained contact with neighboring communities and the world community. They choose to remain isolated, and are referred to as indigenous peoples in voluntary isolation. Estimates suggest there are between 100 and 200 uncontacted tribes, totaling up to 10,000 individuals, primarily located in South America, especially northern Brazil. Knowledge about these groups is mainly gathered from neighboring Indigenous communities and aerial footage.

Definition 🔗

The term “uncontacted peoples” refers to Indigenous groups who have remained largely isolated, maintaining their traditional lifestyles independently from political or governmental entities. While most Indigenous groups have had some form of contact due to European exploration and colonization, “uncontacted” signifies a lack of sustained contact with the majority of non-Indigenous society today. The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights calls them “Indigenous peoples in voluntary isolation,” defined by their rejection of contact with outsiders, including those who previously had contact but chose to return to isolation. These groups are viewed as contemporaries of modernity, not relics of the past. A 2009 United Nations report also includes “peoples in initial contact” who are beginning to integrate into mainstream society. International organizations emphasize their agency by calling them “Indigenous peoples in isolation” or “in voluntary isolation,” also known as “hidden peoples” or “uncontacted tribes.” Historically, European colonial ideas about uncontacted peoples were influenced by the search for Prester John and the Ten Lost Tribes of Israel, identifying them as “lost tribes.”

Relations with Outsiders 🔗

International organizations emphasize protecting indigenous peoples’ lands and environment, preventing exploitation and abuse, and avoiding contact to prevent the spread of modern diseases. Historic exploitation has led governments to grant legal protection and land rights to uncontacted peoples, such as in the Vale do Javari in Brazil and North Sentinel Island in India. In 1961, British explorer Richard Mason was killed by the Panará tribe. Contact in 1973, when the BR-163 road was built through their territory, led to disease and environmental degradation, killing over 250 of the 350 Panará members within a year.

Contention often arises from governments’ desire to extract natural resources. In Brazil, the government attempted assimilation in the 1960s and 1970s, but in 1987, the Department of Isolated Indians (FUNAI) was created, securing protected lands. In Colombia, contact with the Nukak tribe by an evangelical group led to respiratory infections, clashes with drug traffickers, and the death of over half the tribe, resulting in government relocation and poverty. Exploitation for lumbering, ranching, oil prospecting, and poaching poses significant dangers. Former Peruvian President Alan García claimed uncontacted groups were a “fabrication of environmentalists.” In 2016, a Chinese mining subsidiary in Bolivia ignored signs of encroaching on uncontacted tribes. Missionaries can also cause great damage.

In 2014, Acre Indians contacted the Brazilian government due to threats from cocaine traffickers, indicating awareness of the outside world and strategic decisions to avoid contact. Satellite images show tribes migrating away from roads and logging. Indigenous rights activists advocate for leaving isolated peoples alone to protect their self-determination. FUNAI collaborates with experts to make controlled initial contact, operating trading posts for metal tools and cooking instruments, preventing conflicts, and delivering vaccinations. However, FUNAI reported receiving only 15% of its requested budget in 2017. In 2018, FUNAI released videos and images of tribes to raise public awareness and protect them from commercial pressures, investigating a possible mass homicide against the Flecheiros tribe.

The United Nations Human Rights Council (2009) and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (2013) introduced guidelines including the right to choose self-isolation. Reports of “human safaris” in India’s Andaman Islands and the Peruvian Amazon, where tourists seek to view uncontacted peoples, are controversial.

By Region 🔗

India 🔗

Sentinelese 🔗

The Sentinelese people of North Sentinel Island reject contact, often with lethal force. Their language differs significantly from other Andaman languages, suggesting millennia of isolation. Experts consider them the most isolated people in the world. Indian visits to the island ceased in 1997. In 2018, John Allen Chau, an American missionary, was killed while illegally visiting the island. In 2025, a US citizen was arrested for making an unauthorized landing on the island. Survival International condemned these actions, noting the vulnerability of uncontacted peoples to contact-induced diseases.

Shompen 🔗

The Shompen are the Indigenous people of Great Nicobar Island, with an estimated population of 300 in 2001. They practice a hunter-gatherer economy. Survival International identifies them as one of the most isolated peoples, with most refusing interactions with outsiders. The proposed Great Nicobar Development Plan, including an airport, international port, and industrial park, threatens their way of life. In February 2024, 39 genocide experts warned that the development would be a “death sentence” for the Shompen due to increased population and exposure to outside diseases.

South America 🔗

Bolivia 🔗

The Toromona are an uncontacted people living near the Madidi and Heath Rivers. The government has created a protected area within Madidi National Park for them. Among the Ayoreo people of the Gran Chaco, a small number of uncontacted nomadic hunter-gatherers reside in the Kaa-Iya del Gran Chaco National Park. Pacahuaras are believed to be living in voluntary isolation in Pando Department.

Brazil 🔗

Until the 1970s, Brazil attempted to move people on commercially cultivatable lands. In 1987, the Department of Isolated Indians (FUNAI) was established, and the Vale do Javari was declared perpetually sealed off. In 2007, FUNAI reported 67 uncontacted Indigenous peoples, up from 40 in 2005. The Awá people live in the eastern Amazon rainforest, with approximately 350 members, 100 of whom are uncontacted. Their tribe is at risk due to conflicts with logging interests. The Kawahiva live in northern Mato Grosso, constantly moving and known primarily from physical evidence. In 2013, the government released video of the Kawahiva filmed in 2011. In 2025, FUNAI confirmed that the demarcation of the Kawahiva do Rio Pardo territory will happen by the end of 2025. The Korubu live in the lower Vale do Javari. The Flecheiros (“arrow people”) also live in the Vale do Javari. Other tribes may include the Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau and the Himarimã.

In 2019, two brothers of the Piripkura tribe initiated contact with FUNAI after their fire went out, becoming the focus of the documentary Piripkura. Another man, the “Man of the Hole,” lived alone on 8,000 hectares, digging hundreds of holes. He was found dead in his dwelling in August 2022. Since 2021, uncontacted peoples in Brazil have been threatened by illegal land grabbers, loggers, and gold miners. The government of Jair Bolsonaro signaled its intention to develop the Amazon and reduce Indigenous reservations.

Colombia 🔗

Colombia is regarded as offering maximum protection to uncontacted Indigenous people through tribal reserves and strict patrolling. The Nukak people are nomadic hunter-gatherers living between the Guaviare and Inírida rivers. Groups, including the Carabayo, Yuri, and Passé, reside in Río Puré National Park.

Ecuador 🔗

Two isolated Indigenous peoples of Ecuador live in the Amazon region: the Tagaeri and the Taromenane, both eastern Huaorani peoples living in Yasuni National Park. These semi-nomadic people live in small groups, subsisting on hunting, gathering, and some crops. Since 2007, national policy mandates untouchability, self-determination, equality, and no contact. In 2013, more than 20 Taromenane were killed by Waorani, another Huaorani group.

Paraguay 🔗

Approximately 100 Ayoreo people, some of whom are in the Totobiegosode tribe, live uncontacted in the forest. They are nomadic hunter-gatherers in Amotocodie. They are the last uncontacted peoples south of the Amazon Basin, threatened by illegal deforestation. Brazilian company Yaguarete Porá S.A. is converting their ancestral territory into cattle ranching land. The Union of Ayoreo Natives of Paraguay is working for their protection, with support from the Iniciativa Amotocodie. In 2021, the Ayoreo appealed to the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights to save their land.

Peru 🔗

The Nomole (Mashco-Piro) are nomadic Arawak-speaking hunter-gatherers who inhabit Manú National Park. In 1998, their number was estimated at 100 to 250. They speak a dialect of the Piro languages. Amid incursions on their land, the tribe has made it clear they do not wish to be contacted. In July 2024, video and images of dozens of uncontact

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncontacted_peoples

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” which are names given in ufology to humanoid races purportedly from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones. George Adamski is noted as one of the first to report contact with these beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding them often includes telepathy, benevolence, and physical beauty.

History 🔗

This section discusses the historical context and cultural influences related to the Nordic alien phenomenon. David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” associating Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection. These aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned with Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal and youthful. While popular in the 1950s, claims of encounters became less common as the grey alien archetype rose to prominence.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted 🔗

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens. These include Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski, From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger, The Walton Experience by Travis Walton, and Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites). The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends.”

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and figures in ufology, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books and academic papers.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to Wikimedia Commons for media related to Nordic aliens.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_aliens

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” a type of humanoid extraterrestrial beings often discussed in ufology. These beings are said to originate from the Pleiades star cluster and are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans. They are typically depicted as taller than average humans (6-7 ft), with blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention skin tones of pale blue/grey or pastel purple.

George Adamski, a Polish-American ufologist, is noted as one of the first to publicly claim contact with Nordic beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding these beings often includes themes of telepathy, benevolence, beauty, and grace. Telepathy is often described as the primary form of communication.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical context and cultural influences surrounding the Nordic alien narrative.

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories of Nordic-type aliens. The film features an extraterrestrial arriving on Earth to warn humanity about the dangers of atomic weapons.

Bates College professor Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” noting that Nordic aliens are often associated with spiritual growth, love, and protection among believers.

Nordic aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

Claims of encounters with Nordic aliens were common in Europe during the 1950s but became less frequent in later decades, as the grey alien became more prevalent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted 🔗

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens.

The books mentioned include:

  • Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski
  • From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger
  • The Walton Experience by Travis Walton
  • Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites)

The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends”.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and figures within the realm of ufology and extraterrestrial beliefs.

The list includes:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to media related to Nordic aliens on Wikimedia Commons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_alien

item.title: Search for extraterrestrial intelligence
item.description:
Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI) 🔗

The search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) encompasses various scientific projects aimed at detecting signals or evidence of intelligent life beyond Earth. These efforts involve monitoring electromagnetic radiation, searching for optical signals, and investigating potential extraterrestrial artifacts. Some initiatives, like NASA’s Golden Record, have also attempted to send messages to hypothetical alien civilizations. Despite decades of searching, no confirmed evidence of alien intelligence has been found.

History 🔗

This section details the historical progression of SETI efforts, from early speculations to modern scientific projects.

Early Work 🔗

Early searches for extraterrestrial intelligence within the Solar System are highlighted. Nikola Tesla suggested using his wireless electrical transmission system to contact beings on Mars in 1896. In 1899, he thought he detected a signal from Mars at his Colorado Springs experimental station. Guglielmo Marconi, Lord Kelvin, and David Peck Todd also believed radio could be used to contact Martians in the early 1900s. In 1924, during a close opposition of Mars, the United States observed a “National Radio Silence Day” to listen for Martian signals, with William F. Friedman assigned to translate any potential messages.

Project Ozma and Early Radio Astronomy 🔗

The possibility of searching the microwave spectrum was first pointed out in a 1959 paper by Philip Morrison and Giuseppe Cocconi. In 1960, Frank Drake performed the first modern SETI experiment, Project Ozma, at Green Bank, West Virginia, examining the stars Tau Ceti and Epsilon Eridani. Soviet scientists also took a strong interest in SETI during the 1960s. Iosif Shklovsky wrote the book Universe, Life, Intelligence (1962), which was expanded upon by Carl Sagan as Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966). John D. Kraus’s “Big Ear” radio telescope at Ohio State University began the world’s first continuous SETI program.

Project Cyclops and the Wow! Signal 🔗

In 1971, NASA funded a SETI study that proposed the construction of an Earth-based radio telescope array with 1,500 dishes known as Project Cyclops. The project was not built, but the report formed the basis of much SETI work that followed. The Ohio State SETI program gained fame on August 15, 1977, when Jerry Ehman witnessed a strong signal, the Wow! signal, which is considered by some to be the best candidate for a radio signal from an extraterrestrial source ever discovered.
