In May 2023, a test extraterrestrial signal was transmitted to radio telescopes on Earth.

Sentinel, META, and BETA 🔗

In 1980, Carl Sagan, Bruce Murray, and Louis Friedman founded the U.S. Planetary Society, partly as a vehicle for SETI studies. In the early 1980s, Harvard University physicist Paul Horowitz proposed the design of a spectrum analyzer specifically intended to search for SETI transmissions. This work led to “Suitcase SETI” in 1981, followed by Project META in 1985, and Project BETA in 1995. On March 23, 1999, the 26-meter radio telescope on which Sentinel, META and BETA were based was blown over by strong winds and seriously damaged, forcing the BETA project to cease operation.

MOP and Project Phoenix 🔗

In 1978, the NASA SETI program was heavily criticized by Senator William Proxmire, and funding for SETI research was removed from the NASA budget by Congress in 1981. In 1992, the U.S. government funded an operational SETI program, in the form of the NASA Microwave Observing Program (MOP). MOP was canceled one year after its start. In 1995, the SETI Institute resurrected the MOP program under the name of Project Phoenix, under the direction of Jill Tarter. From 1995 through March 2004, Phoenix conducted observations at the Parkes radio telescope in Australia, the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Green Bank, West Virginia, and the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico.

Ongoing Radio Searches 🔗

This section discusses the current state of radio-based SETI projects and the rationale behind focusing on radio frequencies.

Many radio frequencies penetrate Earth’s atmosphere well, leading to the development of radio telescopes. Human endeavors emit considerable electromagnetic radiation, which could be recognizable as artificial signals. Earth has been sending radio waves into space for over 100 years, reaching over 1,000 stars. Many international radio telescopes are currently being used for radio SETI searches, including the Low Frequency Array (LOFAR) in Europe, the Murchison Widefield Array (MWA) in Australia, and the Lovell Telescope in the United Kingdom.

Allen Telescope Array 🔗

The SETI Institute collaborated with the Radio Astronomy Laboratory at the Berkeley SETI Research Center to develop the Allen Telescope Array (ATA). The array has 42 operational dishes at the Hat Creek Radio Observatory in rural northern California. The SETI Institute’s Center for SETI Research (CSR) uses ATA in the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, observing 12 hours a day, 7 days a week. Berkeley astronomers used the ATA to pursue several science topics until 2011, when the collaboration between the University of California, Berkeley and the SETI Institute was terminated. In 2012, the ATA was revitalized with a donation by Franklin Antonio.

SERENDIP 🔗

SERENDIP (Search for Extraterrestrial Radio Emissions from Nearby Developed Intelligent Populations) is a SETI program launched in 1979 by the Berkeley SETI Research Center. SERENDIP analyzes deep space radio telescope data that it obtains while other astronomers are using the telescopes. The most recently deployed SERENDIP spectrometer, SERENDIP VI, was installed at both the Arecibo Telescope and the Green Bank Telescope in 2014–2015.

Breakthrough Listen 🔗

Breakthrough Listen is a ten-year initiative with $100 million funding begun in July 2015 to actively search for intelligent extraterrestrial communications in the universe. The science program for Breakthrough Listen is based at Berkeley SETI Research Center. The project is observing for thousands of hours every year on two major radio telescopes, the Green Bank Observatory in West Virginia, and the Parkes Observatory in Australia. Frank Drake was one of the scientists on the project’s advisory committee. In October 2019, Breakthrough Listen started a collaboration with scientists from the TESS team to look for signs of advanced extraterrestrial life.

FAST 🔗

China’s 500 meter Aperture Spherical Telescope (FAST) lists detecting interstellar communication signals as part of its science mission. FAST is the first radio observatory built with SETI as a core scientific goal. On 14 June 2022, astronomers, working with China’s FAST telescope, reported the possibility of having detected artificial signals, but cautioned that further studies were required to determine if a natural radio interference may be the source. Dan Werthimer noted, “These signals are from radio interference; they are due to radio pollution from earthlings, not from E.T.”

UCLA 🔗

Since 2016, University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) undergraduate and graduate students have been participating in radio searches for technosignatures with the Green Bank Telescope. Targets include the Kepler field, TRAPPIST-1, and solar-type stars.

Community SETI Projects 🔗

This section highlights SETI projects that rely on the contributions of volunteers and the general public.

SETI@home 🔗

The SETI@home project used volunteer computing to analyze signals acquired by the SERENDIP project. The SETI@home project was launched by the Berkeley SETI Research Center at the University of California, Berkeley, in May 1999. The project is run by director David P. Anderson and chief scientist Dan Werthimer. On March 31, 2020, the project stopped sending out new work to SETI@home users, bringing this particular SETI effort to an indefinite hiatus.

SETI Net 🔗

SETI Network was the only fully operational private search system. SETI Net started operation in the early 1980s as a way to learn about the science of the search, and developed several software packages for the amateur SETI community. SETI Net went dark and was decommissioned on 2021-12-04.

The SETI League and Project Argus 🔗

Founded in 1994 in response to the United States Congress cancellation of the NASA SETI program, The SETI League, Incorporated is a membership-supported nonprofit organization. This grass-roots alliance of amateur and professional radio astronomers is headed by executive director emeritus H. Paul Shuch. The organization concentrates on coordinating a global network of small, amateur-built radio telescopes under Project Argus, an all-sky survey seeking to achieve real-time coverage of the entire sky.

Optical Experiments 🔗

This section discusses the search for extraterrestrial intelligence using optical wavelengths, such as lasers.

Some SETI researchers have considered the possibility that alien civilizations might be using powerful lasers for interstellar communications at optical wavelengths. There are two problems with optical SETI: lasers are highly “monochromatic”, and lasers are highly directional

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SETI

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no such life has been conclusively detected, it could range from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The science dedicated to studying extraterrestrial life is astrobiology.

Context 🔗

This section provides a framework for understanding the topic of life in the universe. It outlines various aspects, including planetary habitability within and outside the Solar System, and lists celestial bodies like Venus, Mars, Europa, Enceladus, and Titan as potential locations for life. It also mentions the habitability of binary star systems, natural satellites, neutron star systems, red dwarf systems, K-type, yellow dwarf, and F-type main-sequence star systems.

Likelihood of Existence 🔗

This section explores the debate on whether extraterrestrial life is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous life, citing the size and age of the universe, the abundance of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws. Scientists like Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are mentioned as proponents of this view, which is rooted in the Copernican and mediocrity principles.

Conversely, the Rare Earth hypothesis suggests that life on Earth is due to a unique combination of factors, making extraterrestrial life, especially multicellular life, rare.

The Drake equation, devised by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic argument to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy. The equation considers factors like the rate of star formation, the fraction of stars with planets, and the likelihood of life evolving intelligence and developing communication technology. However, the section notes the controversy surrounding the Drake equation due to the speculative nature of its variables.

The Fermi paradox, the apparent contradiction between the high probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for them, is also mentioned.

Biochemical Basis 🔗

This section discusses the potential biochemical requirements for extraterrestrial life. It states that life requires an environment with non-equilibrium thermodynamics, such as energy from stars, volcanoes, or hydrothermal vents. Liquid water is considered essential as a solvent for biochemical reactions, although alternatives like ammonia or liquid hydrocarbons are mentioned.

The section also explores alternative chemical elements that could form the basis of life, such as silicon, while acknowledging carbon’s versatility. It discusses the potential for radically different biochemistries, the role of natural selection, and the likelihood of cell membranes. Simon Conway Morris is mentioned for his views on convergent evolution leading to similar lifeforms as on Earth.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life 🔗

This section highlights that while conditions on other planets may seem too extreme to harbor life, some of the earliest life forms on Earth originated in extreme environments. Hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs are mentioned as possible origins of life on Earth. These environments support chemosynthetic processes, allowing organisms to utilize energy through reduced chemical compounds that fix carbon. The section suggests that similar processes could occur on other planets with reducing atmospheres.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System 🔗

This section examines the potential for life on various bodies within our Solar System. Besides Earth, Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely candidates. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that evolved differently from Earth. Mars is considered potentially habitable in the past, with the possibility of fossilized remains or surviving microbes underground.

Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto are mentioned as having subsurface oceans, with Europa being the most promising due to contact between its ocean and rocky surface. Enceladus is noted for its eruption columns releasing water into space, containing complex organic molecules, salts, and evidence of hydrothermal activity. Titan is unique for having liquid bodies of hydrocarbons on its surface, raising speculation about lifeforms with different biochemistry.

Scientific Search 🔗

This section introduces astrobiology as the science dedicated to searching for and studying life in the universe. It mentions the direct and indirect methods used, including the identification of thousands of exoplanets.

Search for Basic Life 🔗

This section focuses on the search for biosignatures within the Solar System and beyond. It mentions claims of evidence for microbial life on Mars, including structures resembling nanobacteria in the ALH84001 meteorite. The Viking Mars landers’ gas emission experiments are discussed, along with NASA’s Curiosity rover’s mission to assess past and present habitability on Mars.

Scientists at Cornell University are creating a catalog of microorganisms and their reactions to sunlight to aid in the search for similar organisms on exoplanets. The discovery of organic molecules in meteorites found in Antarctica is also mentioned, suggesting that building blocks of life may be generated within asteroids and comets.

The detection of glycolaldehyde, a sugar molecule needed to form RNA, in a distant star system is highlighted as evidence that complex organic molecules may form in stellar systems prior to planet formation. The discovery of hydrogen cyanide in the plumes of Enceladus is also mentioned as a possible chemical essential for life.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences 🔗

This section discusses the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) through the detection of technosignatures, such as interstellar communications, atmospheric effects, and planetary-sized structures. Organizations like the SETI Institute are searching for radio waves and laser pulses. The use of artificial intelligence to analyze data is also mentioned.

Potential technosignatures include nitrogen dioxide in the atmosphere, chlorofluorocarbons, and light pollution. The Kardashev scale is introduced, suggesting that advanced civilizations may consume energy directly from their local star, creating detectable infrared radiation.

Extrasolar Planets 🔗

This section focuses on the search for exoplanets that may be conducive to life, particularly terrestrial planets within habitable zones. It mentions the discovery of thousands of exoplanets, ranging in size from Earth-like to gas giants. The Kepler space telescope’s role in detecting candidate planets is highlighted.

The section notes that there is at least one planet on average per star, and about 1 in 5 Sun-like stars have an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone. Proxima Centauri b is mentioned as the nearest known exoplanet. The study of planetary habitability considers various factors in determining a planet’s suitability for hosting life.

History and Cultural Impact 🔗

This section explores the historical and cultural context of the extraterrestrial life debate.

Cosmic Pluralism 🔗

This section discusses the philosophical belief in numerous worlds beyond Earth that might harbor life. It traces the concept back to ancient Greek thinkers like Anaximander, Epicurus, and Aristotle. Epicurus believed that other worlds with their own animals and plants should exist, while Aristotle thought Earth was the only planet in the universe. Medieval Muslim writers like Fakhr al-Din al-Razi and Muhammad al-Baqir are mentioned for supporting cosmic pluralism based on the Qur’an.

Early Modern Period 🔗

This section covers the shift in understanding the cosmos during the Copernican Revolution. Nicolaus Copernicus proposed that planets revolve around the sun, Johannes Kepler discovered that orbits were ellipses, and Galileo Galilei’s telescope provided further evidence. Giordano Bruno argued for an infinite universe with every star surrounded by its own planetary system. Isaac Newton’s theory of gravity further strengthened the heliocentric model.

19th Century 🔗

This section discusses the increased speculation about life on Mars in the late 19th century, fueled by telescopic observations of apparent Martian canals. Percival Lowell published books proposing that the canals were the work of a long-gone civilization. Spectroscopic analysis by William Wallace Campbell showed that neither water nor oxygen was present in the Martian atmosphere. Louis Pasteur disproved the theory of spontaneous generation.

Recent History 🔗

This section discusses the emergence of astrobiology as a science. It mentions the influence of science fiction on popular perception and the emergence of pseudosciences like ufology and the ancient astronauts hypothesis.

Lewis White Beck’s analysis of philosophical thought on extraterrestrial life is mentioned. The section notes that while no extraterrestrial life has been found, scientific reasons and technological advances suggest that it can exist elsewhere.

Frank Drake’s optimism about finding alien life is contrasted with Jacques Monod’s pessimism. Peter Ward and Donald Brownlee’s Rare Earth hypothesis is introduced, claiming that Earth-like life is rare in the universe. Stephen Hawking warned against contacting alien life forms, citing the potential for exploitation. Yuri Milner and the SETI Institute launched the Breakthrough Initiatives to expand efforts to search for extraterrestrial life.

Government Responses 🔗

This section discusses government policies related to extraterrestrial life. The 1967 Outer Space Treaty and the 1979 Moon Agreement define rules of planetary protection. COSPAR also provides guidelines for planetary protection. The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs discussed strategies for interacting with extraterrestrial life, but ended without conclusions.

NASA’s Office of Safety and Mission Assurance (OSMA) is mentioned for its mission to prevent backward contamination of Earth by extraterrestrial life. The Chinese government’s space program includes the search for extraterrestrial life. Dmitry Rogozin, head of the Russian space agency, stated that the search for extraterrestrial life is a main goal of deep space research. The French space agency (CNES) has an office for the study of “non-identified aero spatial phenomena”.

In Fiction 🔗

This section discusses the portrayal of extraterrestrials in fiction. Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution influenced science fiction authors to create bizarre aliens distinct from humans. The Barney and Betty Hill incident, the first recorded claim of an alien abduction, influenced the grey alien archetype.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts 🔗

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected the development of cultures, technologies, religions, and even human biology. A common idea is that deities in many religions were actually extraterrestrials, and their advanced technologies were seen as divine powers by early humans.

This idea is rejected by academics and archaeologists, who consider it pseudoarchaeology and unscientific. Claims are often based on distorted or fabricated evidence. Some critics argue that ancient astronaut theories have racist implications, diminishing the achievements of indigenous cultures.

Notable proponents in the late 20th century include Robert Charroux, Jacques Bergier, Jean Sendy, Erich von Däniken, Alexander Kazantsev, Zecharia Sitchin, Robert K. G. Temple, Giorgio A. Tsoukalos, David Hatcher Childress, Peter Kolosimo, and Mauro Biglino.

Overview 🔗

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI.

Believers often claim that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence that landed on Earth in the past. They suggest that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient alien visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that extraterrestrials built or helped humans build structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Evidence is said to come from gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as artifacts that are considered anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people. These “out-of-place artifacts” include artwork and legends reinterpreted to support extraterrestrial contact.

The idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to promote theories of an alternate past, often incorporating white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents portray themselves as an oppressed minority of academics challenging mainstream archaeology, despite lacking credentials.

Like past archaeological endeavors, the focus is on monumental structures, suggesting that indigenous people could not have built them without alien help. However, some indigenous voices argue that ancient alien theory supports their stories of extraterrestrial origins.

A common theme is the portrayal of aliens as light-skinned or Aryan, as claimed by Erich von Däniken. Some proponents are associated with white supremacism.

Mainstream archaeologists have largely ignored these claims, while popular science explainers and skeptics have criticized them. Carl Sagan noted that cases of apparent interest have reasonable alternative explanations, misreporting, or are hoaxes and distortions.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents 🔗

Paleocontact narratives appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and Erich von Däniken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von Däniken’s claims. By the early 1980s, support dwindled.

Shklovskii and Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966) with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky. In Broca’s Brain (1979), Sagan expressed disapproval of writers like von Däniken who treated speculations as valid evidence of extraterrestrial contact. Sagan noted that many legends, artifacts, and out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be explained with conventional hypotheses. He reiterated that extraterrestrial visits were possible but unproven and improbable.

Erich von Däniken 🔗

Erich von Däniken became a leading proponent in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his book Chariots of the Gods? (1968) and its sequels.

Von Däniken argued that certain artifacts required more advanced technology than was available to ancient cultures. He claimed that these artifacts were constructed by extraterrestrial visitors or humans who learned from them. Examples include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

He wrote that ancient art and iconography depict air and space vehicles, intelligent non-human creatures, ancient astronauts, and advanced technology. He also stated that geographically separated cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. One example is his interpretation of the sarcophagus lid from the tomb of Pacal the Great in Palenque, which he saw as a seated astronaut, while Maya texts identify it as a portrait of the ruler with the World Tree.

Von Däniken interpreted the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, whose technology was seen as supernatural. He stated that religious traditions contain references to alien visitors, such as Ezekiel’s revelation, which he interpreted as a landing spacecraft.

His hypotheses became popularized in the U.S. through the NBC-TV documentary In Search of Ancient Astronauts and the film Chariots of the Gods.

Critics argue that von Däniken misrepresented data, made unfounded claims, and failed to validate his core claims. Christian creationists also criticized his work.

Regarding the Nazca Lines, von Däniken stated that they resembled an airfield when seen from the air. Kenneth L. Feder argues that readers seeing the Nazca Lines in a book about aliens would be more likely to associate them with extraterrestrial origins.

In 1970, von Däniken admitted that the Nazca markings could have been laid out using a system of coordinates.

Zecharia Sitchin 🔗

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru orbits the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit. Modern astronomy has found no evidence to support these ideas.

Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story of 50 Anunnaki from Nibiru who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers, creating Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended that the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the end of the last ice age.

His work has not received mainstream scholarly support and has been criticized by professionals. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations are inconsistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform dictionaries.

Alan F. Alford, author of Gods of the New Millennium, initially adhered to Sitchin’s hypotheses but later found fault, stating that the gods personified the falling sky and that the descent of the gods was a poetic rendition of the cataclysm myth.

Robert Temple 🔗

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He cites advanced astronomical knowledge, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations. His work draws on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.

His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies and suggest that the Dogon may have received their astronomical information recently from European sources.

UFO Religions 🔗

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, Raëlism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many see ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities suggesting that members associate enchantment with science fiction memes.

Claims of Proponents 🔗

The scientific consensus is that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts 🔗

Proponents cite ancient mythologies, suggesting that creation myths of gods descending from the heavens to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to cargo cults, where isolated cultures believed Western ships and cargo were sent from the gods.

The ancient Sumerian myth of Enûma Eliš says humankind was created to serve gods called the “Annunaki.” Proponents believe that the Annunaki were aliens who came to Earth to mine gold and created the human race as slaves.

Ramayana 🔗

In Hindu mythology, the gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. The Ramayana mentions these flying objects, used by the Lankan king Ravana from Sri Lanka.

Examples from the Ramayana include descriptions of the Pushpak chariot, a

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: Roswell That Ends Well
item.description:
Roswell That Ends Well 🔗

“Roswell That Ends Well” is the 19th episode of the third season of the animated television series Futurama. It originally aired on December 9, 2001.

Plot 🔗

The Planet Express crew, while observing a supernova, accidentally time travel to 1947 after Fry microwaves a metal pan of popcorn. They crash-land in Roswell, New Mexico, becoming part of the Roswell Incident. Bender is shattered upon impact. The crew searches for a way back to the 31st century. Zoidberg is captured by the U.S. military and experimented on at Roswell Air Base. The military reconstructs Bender’s body into a flying saucer.

The crew needs a microwave oven to return to their time. Professor Farnsworth warns Fry against interacting with his grandfather, Enos, to avoid a grandfather paradox. Fry tries to protect Enos, but Enos dies in a nuclear weapon test. Fry sleeps with Mildred, Enos’s fiancée, and realizes she is his grandmother, making him his own grandfather.

The crew storms Roswell Air Base to steal a microwave dish. Fry and Leela rescue Zoidberg from an alien autopsy. Farnsworth retrieves Bender’s body. While time jumping, Bender’s head is left behind. Back in the 31st century, the crew returns to Roswell, finds Bender’s head, and reattaches it to his body.

Production 🔗

The writing team developed the episode from ideas initially considered for “Anthology of Interest II.” The writers initially avoided time travel in Futurama, but changed their minds. They made the time travel unintentional, triggered by a supernova, to avoid regular time travel. The episode was directed by Rich Moore, who used screen position and character movement to represent time travel. Actions to the left represented the past, while actions to the right indicated progress.

Cultural references 🔗

The episode references time travel stories like Back to the Future and Terminator. It also shares similarities with the Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode “Little Green Men.” Bender’s head buried in the sand is similar to Data’s head in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Enos’s character is based on Gomer Pyle.

Broadcast and reception 🔗

“Roswell That Ends Well” won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (Programming Less Than One Hour) in 2002. Rich Moore won an Annie Award for directing. IGN ranked it as one of the best Futurama episodes. David X. Cohen considered it one of his favorite episodes. Sci Fi Weekly gave it an “A” grade. Despite critical acclaim, the episode had low ratings during its original airing.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_That_Ends_Well

item.title: Rod (optical phenomenon)
item.description:
Rods (Optical Phenomenon) 🔗

Rods, also known as skyfish, air rods, or solar entities, are elongated visual artifacts that appear in photographic images and video recordings. While cryptozoologists and ufologists consider them paranormal, most optical analyses conclude they are insects moving across the frame during capture.

Optical Analysis 🔗

This section details the scientific explanations for the “rod” phenomenon. Robert Todd Carroll, consulting with entomologist Doug Yanega, identified rods as images of flying insects captured over several wing-beating cycles on video. This creates the illusion of a single, elongated body. A report by “The Straight Dope” also attributes rods to tricks of light and motion blur due to long exposure times when recording flying insects. The section emphasizes that claims of extraordinary or alien origins are often attributed to imagination or hoaxes. China Central Television (CCTV) aired a documentary debunking rods, revealing them to be ordinary insects captured by surveillance cameras. Scientists at Tonghua Zhenguo Pharmaceutical Company in Tonghua City, Jilin Province, captured “rods” in nets, finding them to be moths and other insects. UFO investigator Robert Sheaffer, after attending a lecture by Jose Escamilla, concluded that some “rods” were insects moving rapidly, while others were blurred bird wings.

Paranormal Claims 🔗

This section focuses on the paranormal interpretations of rods, particularly those promoted by Jose Escamilla. Escamilla claimed to have filmed the first rods on March 19, 1994, in Roswell, New Mexico, while attempting to film a UFO. He subsequently created videos and gave lectures promoting his claims of rods being alien life forms.

Explanatory Notes 🔗

This section contains a footnote clarifying that claims of rods being extraordinary creatures are often exploited by unscrupulous individuals for profit, according to “Straight Dope” staff.

See Also 🔗

This section lists related topics, including optical phenomena and orbs (optics).

References 🔗

This section provides a list of references used in the article, including:

  • Robert Todd Carroll’s entry on “rods” in The Skeptic’s Dictionary.
  • Doug Yanega’s explanation of rods in “The Straight Dope.”
  • A report from SINA Technology News about CCTV’s documentary debunking rods.
  • Robert Sheaffer’s article “ET, You’ve Got Mail” in Skeptical Inquirer.

External Links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources, including:

  • Jose Escamilla’s “Rods” Video Sequences.
  • Brian Dunning’s Skeptoid podcast episode on rods.
  • A video of “rods” at the Cave of the Swallows.
  • A detailed video analysis of rods.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_(ufology)

item.title: First contact (anthropology)
item.description:
First Contact (Anthropology) 🔗

First contact, in anthropology, refers to the initial meeting between two communities that were previously unaware of each other. This phenomenon is often associated with significant cultural and societal impacts.

Consequences 🔗

When cultures with vastly different technological advancements meet, the more technologically advanced society often has a disruptive advantage. This can lead to dire consequences for the less advanced society. Disease transmission also plays a critical role, as isolated populations often lack immunity to illnesses carried by the more urbanized society. The relative sizes of the populations involved can also influence intercultural development. Outcomes of first contact can range from social integration and colonization to elimination (genocide).

History 🔗

Before contemporary instances of contact with uncontacted peoples, many communities and states were isolated from each other, possessing limited knowledge of one another. The limited formal contact between Europe and China via the Silk Road and later with the Mongol Empire is one such example. European powers, such as Prince Henry the Navigator of Portugal, sought to reach Greater India, leading to the mistaken identification of the Americas as the West Indies and the indigenous peoples of the Americas as “Indians.” This “discovery” has been criticized as one-sided and has parallels in contemporary narratives of first contact beyond Earth, such as the Pioneer plaque. Colonialism often used first contact as a means to control knowledge and representation of “the other,” objectifying contact and its place on the frontier.

Notable Examples 🔗

Numerous instances of first contact have occurred throughout history, including Alexander the Great’s invasions from Persia to India in 330 BC and the establishment of Romano-Chinese relations in the 2nd century AD. However, well-established trade routes meant that many cultures were aware of each other before they met.

Some specific examples include:

  • ~1000: Vikings, led by Leif Erikson, established a settlement at L’Anse Aux Meadows (present-day Canada) and encountered the Beothuk people (referred to as Skræling). The nature of this contact (peaceful or violent) is debated.
  • 12 October 1492: Christopher Columbus’s first voyage led to contact between the Spanish Empire and the Taíno, Galibi, and Ciboney peoples in the West Indies. This contact was violent and resulted in numerous deaths, enslavement, and subjugation of the indigenous inhabitants.
  • 17 June 1579: Francis Drake’s circumnavigation brought the English into contact with the Coast Miwok in Northern California. Relations remained peaceful during Drake’s month-long stay, during which he claimed the land for England as Nova Albion.
  • 21 July 1595: Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira led a Spanish expedition to the Marquesas Islands (French Polynesia), resulting in initial friendly contact with the Polynesians that quickly turned violent, leading to 200 local deaths in the first two weeks.
  • 19 December 1642: Abel Tasman’s first voyage led to contact between the Dutch and the Ngāti Tūmatakōkiri in New Zealand. The encounter resulted in the death of four Dutch and the wounding of one Māori, with no further communication.
  • 19 January 1788: James Cook’s third voyage brought the British into contact with the Native Hawaiians on Kauai, Hawaii. General friendly trade occurred, but one Indigenous Hawaiian was killed.
  • 21 January 1788: The First Fleet’s arrival in Sydney, Australia, led to contact between the British Empire and the Cadigal and Bidjigal peoples. The initial contact was friendly but reserved, with one aborigine likely beaten.
  • 29 November 1791: William R. Broughton led a British expedition to Chatham Island, New Zealand, resulting in contact with the Moriori people. Initial shows of aggression by the Moriori were followed by peaceful relations, but a fight led to the death of one Moriori.
  • 1930: Mick Leahy led an Australian expedition to the New Guinea Highlands, resulting in contact with the Papuan people. The contact was friendly, with some Highland people believing the Australians were their ancestors and attempting to rub off their white skins.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(anthropology)

item.title: Alien TV (2019 TV series)
item.description:
Alien TV (2019 TV series) 🔗

Alien TV is a live-action/CG animation television series that premiered on 9Go! in Australia on November 23, 2019, and on Netflix. The show was created by Ian Brown and developed by Doug Hadders and Adam Rotstein. The series follows a television news crew of extraterrestrials named Ixbee, Pixbee, and Squee, who are sent to Earth to learn about the planet.

Cast 🔗

The main voice cast includes Rob Tinkler as Ixbee, Julie Lemieux as Pixbee, John Cleland as Squee, Kyle Dooley as Squood, and Rupert Degas as the Translator.

Episodes 🔗

The series consists of two seasons. Season 1 was released on August 21, 2020, and Season 2 was released on March 19, 2021. There are no plans for a season 3.

Series Overview 🔗

The series is divided into two seasons, with 13 episodes each. Season 1 was released in 2020, and Season 2 in 2021. Each episode contains three segments.

Season 1 (2020) 🔗

Season 1 consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. Each segment focuses on the aliens’ experiences with different aspects of Earth culture and activities, such as bicycles, gymnastics, camping, playgrounds, art, gum, gyms, birthdays, restaurants, BBQs, offices, Halloween, pizza, magic, cleaning, arcades, dumplings, presents, junkyards, spas, love, movies, kindergarten, sickness, babies, supermarkets, tea, weddings, Loch Ness, soccer, skateboards, mannequins, survival, toyshops, laundromats, yoga, Santa, trophies, and makeup. Each segment is directed by Ian Brown and written by various writers, including Doug Hadders, Adam Rotstein, Jeff Sager, Brian Hartigan, Shawn Kalb, Cleon Prineas, Laurie Elliott, Bruce Griffiths, Simon Dodd, Jennifer Daley, Thomas Duncan-Watt and Naomi Jardine.

Season 2 (2021) 🔗

Season 2 also consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. The segments continue to explore the aliens’ interactions with Earth, featuring topics such as trains, barbershops, gnomes, florists, fashion, teeth, pools, dinner parties, skiing, joke shops, the Outback, fire halls, baby showers, yard sales, aquariums, dance, international games, shopping, school, holidays, lucha libre, cars, sleep, golf, airplanes, water parks, mail, music, bowling, gardening, museums, Bollywood, castles, ballet, energy, leprechauns, glasses, trials, and scary things. Ian Brown directs all segments, and the writing credits include Naomi Jardine, Jerome Simpson, Bruce Griffiths, Jennifer Daley, Jeff Sager, Kyle Dooley, Simon Dodd, Cleon Prineas, Brian Hartigan, and Gina Roncoli Bruce Griffiths.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_TV

item.title: UFO sightings in Poland
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Poland 🔗

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Poland. It includes specific incidents with dates, locations, and brief descriptions.

10 May 1978, Emilcin 🔗

This section focuses on the Emilcin Abduction, where a farmer in Emilcin claimed to have been abducted and examined by short, green-faced humanoid beings. The encounter allegedly took place inside a white, hovering craft. A memorial now stands at the site of the alleged abduction.

19 January 2009, Jarnołtówek 🔗

This section details a sighting in Jarnołtówek near Prudnik. Adam Maksymów reported seeing a large saucer with a triangular blue beam rising into the sky. The object was accompanied by loud noises and a buzzing sound. Other residents of Jarnołtówek also reported witnessing the same object.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the main “List of reported UFO sightings” article on Wikipedia, allowing readers to explore a broader range of UFO incidents worldwide.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources used to support the claims made in the article. These include news articles from Kraków Post, Nowa Trybuna Opolska, and Gazeta Krakowska. The references provide external verification and further reading on the reported sightings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Poland

item.title: UFO sightings in Belgium
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Belgium 🔗

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Belgium, focusing primarily on the significant wave of sightings between 1989 and 1990.

1989-1990 🔗

This section highlights the Belgian UFO wave, a period of intense UFO activity. The main feature of this wave was the frequent reports of triangular UFOs observed across the country. These objects were even pursued by Belgian Air Force F-16 fighter jets, and some photographs were taken. One speculative explanation suggested these sightings might have been misidentified stealth aircraft, specifically the F-117 Nighthawk, using Belgian highways for navigation.

1990-03-30 🔗

This section details a specific mass sighting event that occurred on March 30, 1990, in Ans, Wallonia. Numerous witnesses reported seeing large, silent, low-flying black triangles. These objects were tracked by multiple NATO radar systems and intercepted by jet fighters. The Belgian military investigated the incident, and photographic evidence is said to exist. A close encounter was also reported during this event.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the general “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia article, allowing readers to explore UFO sightings in other locations and time periods.

External links 🔗

This section includes an external link to the MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) website, specifically to a page displaying the latest 20 UFO sighting reports and pictures. This provides a resource for readers interested in contemporary UFO sighting information.

UFOs Template 🔗

This section contains a template linking to various UFO-related topics on Wikipedia. It includes links to:

  • Ufology: The study of UFOs.
  • Claimed Sightings:
    • A general list of reported UFO sightings.
    • Sightings in outer space and near atomic sites.
    • Sightings from pre-20th century to the 21st century, including notable events like the Roswell incident, the Phoenix Lights, and the USS Nimitz UFO incident.
    • Confirmed hoaxes like the Maury Island hoax and the Alien Autopsy film.
    • Sightings by country, including Africa, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, China, France, Mexico, Russia, Spain, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
  • Types of UFOs: Black triangles, flying saucers, foo fighters, ghost rockets, green fireballs, mystery airships, and space jellyfish.
  • Types of Alleged Extraterrestrial Beings: Energy beings, grey aliens, insectoids, little green men, Nordic aliens, and reptilian humanoids.
  • Studies and Timeline: Projects and reports like Project Sign, Project Blue Book, the Condon Report, and the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program.
  • Hypotheses: Ancient astronauts, extraterrestrial, interdimensional, psychological, and psychosocial hypotheses.
  • Conspiracy Theories: Area 51, Bob Lazar, Dulce Base, and Men in Black.
  • Involvement:
    • Abduction claims, including history, entities, narrative, and perspectives.
    • Other aspects like implants, cattle mutilation, close encounters, contactees, crop circles, government responses, and ufologists.
  • Culture: UFOs in fiction and religions.
  • Skepticism: Links to scientific skeptics and the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry.
  • Government & Law: Mentions United States Congress hearings on UFOs and the Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Disclosure Act (UADPA).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Belgium

item.title: Alien (Britney Spears song)
item.description:
Alien (Britney Spears song) 🔗

“Alien” is a song by Britney Spears from her 2013 album Britney Jean. The song is a mid-tempo dance-pop track about Spears’ feelings of loneliness. It received positive reviews from music critics, who praised its production and personal nature. Despite not being released as a single, it charted on the US Bubbling Under Hot 100 and the French Singles Chart. Spears performed the song during her “Britney: Piece of Me” residency.

Background 🔗

After her time as a judge on The X Factor, Spears began working on her eighth studio album in December 2012. William Orbit was announced as a producer for the project in May 2013. Spears described “Alien,” her collaboration with Orbit, as “really cool” and “really great.” There were initial rumors of a collaboration with Lady Gaga, but this did not happen. A demo version of the song leaked online before the album’s release, which Orbit stated had incorrect chorus notes that were fixed in the final version. Spears considered releasing “Alien” as a single, as revealed in her documentary I Am Britney Jean, but this never materialized. In July 2014, an unedited vocal track of Spears singing the song leaked, drawing criticism for her uncorrected vocals. Orbit defended Spears, stating that the leaked audio was a vocal warm-up and not intended for public release.

Composition 🔗

“Alien” is a midtempo dance-pop song co-written by Spears, William Orbit, Dan Traynor, Ana Diaz, and Anthony Preston, and produced by Orbit and HyGrade. The song’s musical style has been compared to Madonna’s Ray of Light album, which was also produced by Orbit. Lyrically, the song explores themes of loneliness. A vocal glitch at 2:14 in the song sparked discussion, with Orbit joking that it was due to an alien abduction.

Critical Reception 🔗

“Alien” was generally well-received by music critics, who praised its production and personal themes. Critics highlighted Orbit’s production and Spears’ vulnerability on the track. Some reviewers compared the song favorably to Madonna’s work with Orbit. However, one critic felt that Spears’ vocal performance did not match the song’s solemn production.

Live Performances 🔗

Spears performed “Alien” during her “Britney: Piece of Me” residency at Planet Hollywood Las Vegas. One performance was notable because Spears was caught lip-syncing when the backing track continued playing after she missed her cue. The song was later removed from the setlist but was briefly re-added following Spears’ breakup with her boyfriend David Lucado.

Credits and Personnel 🔗

Lists the people involved in the creation of the song, including:

  • Songwriters: Britney Spears, William Orbit, Dan Traynor, Ana Diaz, Anthony Preston
  • Producers: William Orbit, HyGrade
  • Engineers: Alan O’Connell, Alan Tilston, John Hanes, Serban Ghenea
  • Additional Vocals: Ana Diaz

The recording took place at Guerrilla Studios in London and was mixed at MixStar Studios in Virginia Beach, Virginia.

Charts 🔗

“Alien” charted on the French Singles Chart and the US Billboard Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart. It reached number 147 in France and number 8 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 in the US. It also charted in South Korea, reaching number 90 on the Gaon Music Chart.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_(Britney_Spears_song)

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) 🔗

This entry details the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, focusing on the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the story in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 🔗

This subsection outlines the initial reports of the Roswell incident during the “flying disc craze” of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed disc, and the subsequent retraction stating it was a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited 🔗

This subsection explains how the Roswell story gained traction again in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that the debris he recovered was extraterrestrial.

Authors 🔗

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It mentions Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle and their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility.

Contents 🔗

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes the book’s introduction of the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up. It also mentions the claim that the military sought to discredit the growing interest in flying saucers. The section also notes that the authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of those accounts appear in the book. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel.

Alien bodies 🔗

This section details the book’s introduction of the story about Barney Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also mentions the conflation of the Roswell incident with the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception 🔗

This section discusses the reception of the book, noting that critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and that it “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions accusations against Moore regarding the Majestic 12 documents.

Aftermath 🔗

This section mentions Moore’s admission at a 1989 MUFON conference that he had engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views 🔗

This section references the 1993 inquiry by the General Accounting Office in response to US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a 1994 Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: Finnish Air Force UFO sighting
item.description:
Finnish Air Force UFO Sighting 🔗

The Finnish Air Force UFO sighting, also known as “The seven balloons of Pori,” refers to a UFO observation that occurred on April 12, 1969, in Pori, Finland, during military training exercises. This event is notable as the only UFO observation acknowledged by the Finnish Air Force. The Air Force suggested the objects may have been foreign reconnaissance aircraft.

Sighting 🔗

During a Fouga Magister jet training mission at Pori Airport on April 12, 1969, a Finnish Defence Forces flight controller instructed pilot-in-training Tarmo Tukeva to investigate seven airborne objects. These objects were floating at an altitude of approximately 1500-3000 meters above the airport. Tukeva described the objects as ball or disc-shaped but could not accurately determine his distance from them. He reported that the objects accelerated away from him “at great speed.” Radar images, the nature of which remains undetermined, were also reported 200 kilometers away in Vaasa. Jouko Kuronen, another pilot-in-training, stated that he overheard the radio communications between the flight controller and Tukeva and also observed the objects. According to the Finnish Armed Forces magazine Ruotuväki, the reports from April 12 were similar to other cases occurring over bodies of water during ongoing military exercises, suggesting the possibility of “transnational spy planes or aircraft.”

References 🔗

The references section lists the sources used to support the information presented in the article. These include articles from Ilta-Sanomat and Yle Uutiset, both Finnish news outlets. These articles provide further details and context regarding the UFO sighting and the Finnish Air Force’s acknowledgment of the event.

UFOs 🔗

This section provides a comprehensive template of UFO-related topics, including ufology, claimed sightings, types of UFOs, alleged extraterrestrial beings, studies, hypotheses, conspiracy theories, alien involvement, culture, skepticism, government involvement, and related categories. It serves as a navigation tool to explore various aspects of the UFO phenomenon.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finnish_Air_Force_UFO_sighting

item.title: UFO sightings in the United States
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the United States 🔗

This is a list of alleged UFO sightings in the United States.

Table of Sightings 🔗

This table lists alleged UFO sightings in the United States, organized by date, city, and state. It includes a link to a main article for some sightings and a brief description of each event.

September 1865 🔗

  • Location: Cadotte Pass, Montana
  • Description: Trapper James Lumley reported seeing a craft and its subsequent crash, noting sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.

1896–1897 🔗

  • Location: Multiple locations across the United States
  • Description: Alleged sightings of airship-like vehicles, known as the Mystery airships.

April 17, 1897 🔗

  • Location: Aurora, Texas
  • Description: Local residents claimed an airship crashed, and the dead alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery. This is known as the Aurora, Texas, UFO incident.

February 24, 1942 🔗

  • Location: Los Angeles, California
  • Description: The “Battle of Los Angeles,” involved an alleged enemy attack and subsequent anti-aircraft artillery barrage. Initially thought to be an attack from Japan, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox called it a “false alarm.” The US Office of Air Force History attributed it to “war nerves” triggered by a lost weather balloon.

August 1945 🔗

  • Location: Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico
  • Description: Two boys reported seeing an “avocado-shaped” object fall from the sky, alleging it was a crashed vehicle containing three insect-like alien creatures. This is known as the Trinity UFO Case.

June 21, 1947 🔗

  • Location: Maury Island, Washington
  • Description: An incident reported before the Kenneth Arnold sighting, involving an alleged encounter with “men in black suits.”

June 24, 1947 🔗

  • Location: Mount Rainier, Washington
  • Description: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in a chain near Mount Rainier. He described them as bright, erratic, and flying at tremendous speed.

July 1947 🔗

  • Location: Roswell, New Mexico
  • Description: The Roswell UFO Incident involved the recovery of materials near Roswell. The United States military claims it was a crashed research balloon, while ufologists believe it was a crashed alien craft.

January 7, 1948 🔗

  • Location: Maysville, Kentucky
  • Description: The Mantell Incident involved the crash and death of Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, while in pursuit of a UFO.

July 24, 1948 🔗

  • Location: Montgomery, Alabama
  • Description: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter involved two commercial pilots reporting that their Douglas DC-3 nearly collided with a strange torpedo-shaped object.

October 1, 1948 🔗

  • Location: Fargo, North Dakota
  • Description: The Gorman Dogfight involved a US Air Force pilot sighting and pursuing a UFO for 27 minutes.

May 11, 1950 🔗

  • Location: McMinnville, Oregon
  • Description: Paul and Evelyn Trent took the McMinnville UFO photographs on their farm.

May 29, 1950 🔗

  • Location: Mount Vernon, Maryland
  • Description: Captain Willis Sperry and crewmembers on an American Airlines DC-6 reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light of fluorescent type.”

August 15, 1950 🔗

  • Location: Great Falls, Montana
  • Description: The Mariana UFO incident garnered national media attention.

August 25, 1951 🔗

  • Location: Lubbock, Texas
  • Description: The Lubbock Lights were a v-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.

May 24, 1952 🔗

  • Location: Burbank, California
  • Description: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and their friendly human-appearing pilots during his drives home from an aircraft plant.

July 13, 1952 🔗

  • Location: Washington, D.C.
  • Description: The 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident involved a series of unidentified flying object reports.

September 12, 1952 🔗

  • Location: Flatwoods, West Virginia
  • Description: Six local boys and a local woman reported sighting a UFO landing and later discovered a bizarre-looking creature near the site, known as the Flatwoods monster.

November 23, 1953 🔗

  • Location: Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan
  • Description: Felix Moncla, Jr., a United States Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing an unidentified flying object over Lake Superior.

November 2, 1957 🔗

  • Location: Levelland, Texas
  • Description: The Levelland UFO case involved multiple sightings of a UFO in the small town.

September 19, 1961 🔗

  • Location: Lancaster, New Hampshire
  • Description: Betty and Barney Hill claimed to have been abducted by extraterrestrials, in what is known as the Hill Abduction or Zeta Reticuli Incident.

April 24, 1964 🔗

  • Location: Socorro, New Mexico
  • Description: Lonnie Zamora, a New Mexico police officer, reported a UFO close encounter.

September 3, 1965 🔗

  • Location: Exeter, New Hampshire
  • Description: The Exeter incident involved a UFO the size of a barn seen by a teenager and two police officers.

December 9, 1965 🔗

  • Location: Kecksburg, Pennsylvania
  • Description: The Kecksburg UFO incident involved a large, brilliant fireball seen by thousands.

1969 🔗

  • Location: Leary, Georgia
  • Description: Jimmy Carter claimed that he had seen a UFO.

October 11, 1973 🔗

  • Location: Pascagoula, Mississippi
  • Description: The abduction of Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker, also known as the Pascagoula Abduction.

January 12, 1975 🔗

  • Location: North Bergen, New Jersey
  • Description: The Stonehenge incident occurred in the North Hudson Park near the Stonehenge apartment building.

November 5, 1975 🔗

  • Location: Snowflake, Arizona
  • Description: Travis Walton claims to have been abducted by a UFO while working on a logging crew.

December 17, 1977 🔗

  • Location: Council Bluffs, Iowa
  • Description: Local residents reported seeing a reddish fireball falling and disappearing behind trees, followed by a grass fire and molten metal.

August 27, 1979 🔗

  • Location: Stephen, Minnesota
  • Description: Deputy Sheriff Val Johnson’s patrol car was struck by a blinding ball of light.

December 29, 1980 🔗

  • Location: Dayton, Texas
  • Description: The Cash-Landrum Incident involved a reported UFO sighting and subsequent health damage to the witnesses.

November 11, 1987 🔗

  • Location: Gulf Breeze, Florida
  • Description: The Gulf Breeze UFO incident occurred.

March 8, 1994 🔗

  • Location: Multiple locations in Michigan
  • Description: Over 100 witnesses reported five or six objects across West Michigan, known as the 1994 Lake Michigan UFO event.

March 13, 1997 🔗

  • Location: Phoenix, Arizona
  • Description: The Phoenix Lights involved a series of optical phenomena seen by thousands of people.

January 5, 2000 🔗

  • Location: Highland, Illinois
  • Description: The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting involved five on-duty Illinois police officers and other witnesses reporting a massive, silent, triangular aircraft.

August 21, 2004 🔗

  • Location: Chicago, Illinois
  • Description: A triangular formation of reddish lights were seen at low to intermediate altitude.

November 7, 2006 🔗

  • Location: Chicago, Illinois
  • Description: Federal authorities at Chicago O’Hare International Airport received a report of a metallic, saucer-shaped craft hovering over gate C-17.

January 5, 2009 🔗

  • Location: Morristown, New Jersey
  • Description: Five unidentified red objects were seen. It was later admitted to be a hoax.

February 1 🔗
